cluster_classes.class_description: Plant leaf structures that serve as sites for butterfly egg laying and caterpillar feeding, including the general leaf and its specific underside surface.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The eggs are usually laid on the underside of leaves... feeding on leaves and growing rapidly.

members.entity_description: The lower surface of plant leaves where butterfly eggs are commonly laid.
Plant leaves that provide a surface for egg laying and food for caterpillars.

cluster_classes.class_description: Macroscopic structural parts of a plant, such as leaves and stems, that provide support, transport, or surface functions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The caterpillar attaches itself to a leaf or stem and forms a protective shell around itself.

members.entity_description: Flat, typically green plant organ where photosynthesis occurs; serves as an attachment surface for the caterpillar when forming a chrysalis.
Supporting plant axis that transports water and nutrients and can serve as an attachment surface for a caterpillar forming a chrysalis.

args.new_description: Macroscopic plant organs and their surfaces (e.g., leaves, leaf undersides, stems) that provide structure, support, and attachment/feeding surfaces relevant to butterfly eggs, caterpillars, and chrysalides.
args.justification: Both classes cover the same domain of macroscopic plant structures (leaves, leaf undersides, stems) with overlapping entities (leaf/leaves) and shared functional role as surfaces for butterfly life stages, so they should form a single coherent plant-structure class.
The merged class represents macroscopic plant organs and their surfaces, which fits a higher-level Class_Group of plant morphological structures.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes cover the same domain of macroscopic plant structures (leaves, leaf undersides, stems) with overlapping entities (leaf/leaves) and shared functional role as surfaces for butterfly life stages, so they should form a single coherent plant-structure class.
The merged class represents macroscopic plant organs and their surfaces, which fits a higher-level Class_Group of plant morphological structures.
